passages.text: MKT INTEL VIEWS: NVDA delivered a solid print (rev +56%y/y) but the stock is down as this was the smallest % increase in 2 years and results were a bit light of expectations (see our spec sales take here). The stock market reaction across Asia Tech seems to suggest the AI trade remains intact, although reports that China chipmakers are aiming to triple AI chip output next year also helped (within SHCOMP, Tech is the only sector in the green this morning as 85% of stocks are lower). That said, NVDA results + a soft/in- line PCE on Friday, could be conducive of another leg to the broadening the trade (here from Drew) given positioning backdrop (Chart below) and SPX 493 earnings acceleration in 2Q25. The move lower in front- end rates also helps. 2Y1M USD OIS broke below 3% yesterday but likely reflecting the administration effort to reshape the Fed as Inflation expectations creep higher (2yr inflation swaps are now at highest level since late 2022). Continue to watch Gold for possible breakout after a long period of consolidation.
In Europe, a few things.

- Francois Bayrou will hold direct talks with lawmakers next week as he battles to avoid being forced out in a September confidence vote. We wrote on France on Weds- The topic of potential internal rotations has picked up pace again in Europe. The two sectors most watched include Healthcare (bottom of the cycle relative valuations) and Luxury (dislocated to China rally – but with reservations given driver of A shares has been liquidity, not macro - and sustained strength of US consumer). Read more thoughts below from the Desk.- With budgets in focus, there is the usual noise on countries with weak finances. This morning, il Corriere reports that Italy may consider a tax on buybacks of listed firms while yesterday, la Stampa said an extension to a law that forces banks to suspend the use of deferred tax assets is being discussed (raising €1 billion and €1.5 billion). At this point, both are still unconfirmed and don't seem - large enough to alter fundamental pictures (but can create noise)
In terms of catalysts, today we focus on claims and tonight's macro data from Japan (notably Tokyo CPI).

EU BANKS: Sector extended losses, with the first 3 consecutive sessions in the red since Liberation Day week. France uncertainty weighing on European names and positioning remains stretched at \(100^{\text{th}}\) %- ile. Headlines around potential bank tax in Italy have not helped sector.

EU LUXURY: Extends outperformance, with sector prime for mean reversion given underperformance this summer. Sector also lags China equities and proxies (ex. Basic Resources). Positioning remains low at \(36^{\text{th}}\) %- ile, and weakness in banks (long momo), helps the luxury strength (short momo) - same as yday. Flow wise, turned net to buy in the sector over past week.

NVIDIA: Impressive quarter, yet several areas need more clarification. Above all, there remains uncertainty around: 1) networking strength, 2) somewhat slower Blackwell growth (versus cont'd Hopper and even H20 demand), and 3) lack of clarity on China. More importantly, expectations were high. With investor expectations already pricing in a \(\) 7\(EPS, there appears to be nothing concrete in the results to justify a higher stock price

ASEAN EQUITY STRATEGY: Latest rally has been led mainly by domestic investors whilst foreigners continue to remain on the sidelines. Team believes equity bull market will remain intact: base case sees expect lower interest rates, stimulative fiscal policies to boost domestic growth, seasonality (4Q- 1Q) and inexpensive valuation to support markets over the next 6 months

EU OIL & GAS: Team takes stock on key sector metrics and provide a renewed EU Majors Question Bank of pertinent issues to discuss in management meetings. Top ideas: OW Shell, Eni, TotalEnergies and Repsol (for diesel); UW Equinor, OMV.

TODAY'S CATALYSTS: a) EA Money Supply, Consumer Confidence; b) US GDP S Q2, Personal Consumption, Core PCE, Claims; c) ECB July minutes d) Informal meeting of EU defence ministers in Copenhagen; e) UST 7Y \(\) 44\(bn; f) Bitcoin Asia 2025 conference in Hong Kong through Aug. 29; EARNINGS: US: DELL; EA: DG; ASIA: ICBC, Citi Securities, CPIC, ZTE, Li Auto, WES
Source: JPM Spec Sales Survey, Bloomberg, Factset
NDX, RTY (net longs vs OI). Outright and Relative
EU HEALTHCARE P/E (vs SXXP)

Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P. priced as on 22 August 2025.

BANKS WORST SECTOR IN EUROPE TODAY: SX7E - 1.6% today and now down for 3rd consecutive session (- 5% so far this week). Note, not had 3 consecutive sessions in the red in Europe banks since Liberation Day week. Sector still +53% YtD (best sector in Europe by over 20% vs #2). Space was soft in Asia with Hang Seng Mainland Banks Index - 1.4% and Topix Banks - 80bps. France uncertainty weighing on European names, OAT/Bunds spread just shy of 79bps now (vs ~70bps last week). Political risk is back

slightly earlier than expected with Bayrou's motion of confidence on September 8 likely to accelerate the fall of the government. Positioning v high in the space, speaking to JPM Positioning team, overall EMEA banks is at 100% %- tile - hence not a surprise to see the move. Would add unhelpful headlines La Stampa newspaper reported without mentioning where it obtained the information that Italy mulls a new postponement of deferred tax assets due to banks to contribute funding its new budget. This is how banks avoided a new bank tax last year, so looks like the government is considering similar solution to get more money for the budget. As a reminder, the delay in DTAs has no capital impact, no P&L impact. Flow wise - quiet in the space today, but was very busy yday (meaningfully better to sell on high touch on over \(\) 200m\(of notional - while our PT desk was 1.14x better to buy, rebal driven).

LUXURY BEST SECTOR IN EUROPE TODAY: JPM European Luxury basket (JPLX) \(+2\%\) , best sector in Europe and getting incoming re the move. We flagged the outperformance yesterday and sector still feels prime for mean reversion given underperformance over the summer. As flagged yesterday JPLX \(- 2.3\%\) over the summer in USD terms, vs Hang Seng \(+11\%\) , Macau \(+34\%\) and SXPP (Basic Resources) \(+8.5\%\) . Space traded well in HK today with Prada \(+3.5\%\) . Would add a couple of positive snippets overnight with reports (CNBC) that Canada Goose draws take- private bids valuing it at \(\) 1.35\(and PVH raising outlook last night. PVH (Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger) \(+6\%\) after hrs. Q2 25 results overnight - sales broadly in line with guidance at \(+1\%\) ex- FX (guide 'flat to increase slightly'), inc CK \(+3\%\) and Tommy flat yoy. Saw growth in Americas and APAC, offset by decline in EMEA. PVH C/C at 14:00UK. Would add that Swatch is is hosting a "short conference call today with a Q&A session" for sellside and investors "regarding an update on the extraordinary US Tariff situation". Due at 13:00UK today. Helpful tariff headline underpinning sector (tariff sensitive sector) - with reports that EU to propose cutting US tariffs this week to meet Trump demand. Small uptick on this. Finally note Brunello Cucinelli H1 sales due tomorrow after the close. Speaking to JPM Positioning team, Luxury positioning at 36th %- tile. Finally weakness in banks (long momo), helping the luxury strength (short momo) - same as yday. Flow wise, we have turned net to buy in the sector over the past week - not material in size.

- EU: European Equities closed mixed (UKX -0.1%, SX5E 0.2%, SXXP 0.1%) with France recovering some of the political-driven selloff (CAC best performers, +0.4%). We saw an extension of Tuesday's moves, with Banks the worst sector and the Luxury rally extending. Banks took a further hit on reports Italy is considering a new bank tax and German bank downgrades. Internal rotations drove a MOMO unwind, with Longs leading the selloff. EU rates closed generally lower (UK 2Y flat, 10Y -1bps, GE 2Y -2bps, 10Y -2bps) with French long-end yields rising.

- US: US Equities closed higher (SPX 0.2%, NDX 0.2%, RTY 0.6%), into NVDA earnings. Energy stocks led the rally, notably outperforming other sectors (+1.1%). All sectors closed higher, barre Comm Services which closed marginally down (-0.1%). MOMO sold off, which Shorts outperforming. Software was the best performing thematic on the day. US rates closed lower (2Y -4bps, 10Y -3bps).- Asia: APAC stocks are mixed (NKY 0.7%, HSI -1%, CSI 300 0.4%) with HK Equities underperforming regional peers. Focus in HK remains on earnings, with Meituan disappointment dragging HSTECH lower. Japan gains are broad based, with Oil & Gas leading while Banks continue to grind higher. The move in Banks comes despite a weak 2y JGB auction. EU and US futures are mixed (SX5E 0.1%, SPX -0.1%).
POSITIONING INTELLIGENCE IS NOT A PRODUCT OF RESEARCH
Report: Weekly Wrap | Set- up into Jackson Hole / NVDA...Tech Elevated, Broader US Positioning Not, but Modest Pullback Could Still Play Out (Aug 22nd)

Summary: Heading into the key events over the next week, we see some signs that positioning levels are elevated. At the same time, sentiment, recent flows, and market rotations (e.g. cyc/def, beta, and momentum reversals) suggest a more risk- off tone has started to creep in.

Looking at past rebounds from prior lows in our US TPM Level (i.e. lows of - 0.8z or below), the current SPX rebound is on par with some of the best we've seen in the past; however, there's often been a pullback of around 5- 8% over the next 1.5 months. This may not start over the next week, but history suggests it wouldn't be surprising if it were to occur soon.

In addition, while the level of aggregate positioning isn't that high in absolute terms (currently only +0.2z), this is actually fairly similar to the past. Or looked at differently, when we index the level of positioning to the prior lows, the increase from lows has been about on par with past events.

Going back to what was mentioned earlier, there are some signs that positioning levels are a bit high: HF net leverage (near YTD highs), CTA positioning, Asset Mgr positioning in US Eq. futures, and buying of US stocks by EU investors per TIC data.
Despite some of the internal market volatility over the past couple weeks, HF performance has been pretty muted (average +0.7% MTD globally with fairly neutral long- short spreads).

Interestingly, despite the drop in US Momentum's performance, we have not seen a similar drawdown in the most crowded HF stocks (on a long- short basis)...this is similar to the 2H20 through 2021 period. It's too early to tell if this reduced correlation will persist as medium term returns (i.e. 20d rolling returns) still appear closely linked and the correlation between HF crowding and Momentum has been persistently positive since early 2024.

On the sector front, Semis/Mag7 will be in focus next week as well. Overall we see Mag7 positioning remaining elevated as it has been over the past few weeks (i.e., L/S ratio still at \(94^{\text{th}}\) %- tile and net exposure at \(+2z\) ). Semis positioning in N. America also remains around historical highs and it's notable that Info Tech has been the most net bought sector by HFs over the past 5d with Semis and Software both bought. In contrast broader Cyclicals were mostly sold in the past week.

Outside the US, China local stocks have been the most bought in the past week, while HK have been most sold. In addition, the China Anti- Involution theme continues to be in focus and we've seen HF positioning pick up in the China stock beneficiaries basket (JPCHSCBF).

In Europe, HFs were initially adding to shorts this month, but flows have recently started to flip a bit more positively. Notably, despite the recent weakness in EU Defence (JPEUDEFN), we're starting to see HFs come back to the group as longs get added back. In addition, EU Defence Secondary Winners remains a theme with strong HF flows and elevated positioning (L/S ratio at \(96^{\text{th}}\) %- tile since 2018).
Andrew Tyler | Federico Manicardi | Ellen Wang | Victoria Campos |

Data Assets & Alpha – delivering high frequency J. P. Morgan trading data and associated insights from the Market, Data and Positioning Intelligence teams. Available through written product on JP Morgan Markets, conference calls & podcasts via platforms including Apple, Google and Spotify, and data feeds via the DataQuery application & Fusion platform.

High frequency data- driven market insights and trade ideas leveraging macro, fundamental and political inputs
Proprietary data and signals from our industry- leading Markets business, including equity signals, retail sentiment and volatility marks

Proprietary positioning and flows- based data and analysis, based on the J. P. Morgan Prime book, Retail investor and ETF flows, among other sources. Data sets including positioning, flows, crowding, leverage, performance and alpha, and grouped by sector, industry, factor and strategy
